comment._content: Bello trabajo y hermoso el puerto. Un cordial saludo a su inspirado autor

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Ottilie & Renaud Camus: Thanks for keeping us on our toes.  Back in 1905, the original Detroit Publishing Company sales catalog for these photographs categorized all the views of the Channel Islands with Great Britain, and we accepted that information too easily. On top of that, this particular photograph really is England. I've updated the description.  -- Helena (LOC)

comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: Interesting that the post card says, lower left: 'Robin Hood Bay', but this well known and popular place (in North Yorkshire, YO22, UK) is now always rendered as 'Robin Hood's Bay' as on Google Maps and (most reliably of all) on British Ordnance Survey maps.  Other maps sometimes render the name without the apostrophe.

comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20993969@N06] Is this question directed at my comment above? If so, then it's quite simple. It just concerns the history of this place name, which might therefore interest the Library of Congress archivists who have posted this. The name seems to have changed a little (or just rendered differently) since this postcard was made (i.e. in the last 100 years or so), though it turns out that there are sometimes mistakes made with the name too.
